intro: Hornstedtia lophophora, commonly known as the mountain holly, is a flowering plant native to the high elevations of the western United States. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in cool, moist environments. Its leaves are leathery and dark green, while its flowers range in color from white to pink, adding ornamental value to its natural habitat. Hornstedtia lophophora is often found in subalpine and alpine regions, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
